1.content:
The pain, it hurts. Your arms, shoulders, legs, ribs, chest, head; they all hurt.

The last thing you remember is getting the last book you needed to complete your Redwall set. After that, bright lights, and pain.

Suddenly, you feel something; water coming into your nose. You open your eyes and find yourself surrounded. You look up, and see light. You begin to move your arms and legs, trying to get to the surface. Along the way, you see others, but you can't make them out. Finally, you make it to the surface, and gasp for air. Then, something grabs your arms.

"Hey Brother, we just found another one," a voice says.

"Can we throw him back?" another voice asks.

"No, we can not just throw back anyone who has managed to survive the river," says a third voice. "After all, it is our duty to help the sick and injured, as well as the newly revived. Be they woodlander or otherwise."

You look to your sides, however, your vision is blurry. All that you can make out about your saviors are that they are tall and wearing brownish fur coats, which do not make sense. You then look towards the direction of the third voice, and see someone wearing some green clothing.

"Would you two otters hurry up and get that person here," the green one says. "I think they suffered a concussion before they came here."

"And it looks like they swallowed a good deal of water too," said the owner of the first voice.

You also begin to hear other voices, some saying thanks, others telling someone to get their hands off them.

Finally, you manage to get to land, where the green one began to wrap some cloth around your eyes, and you try to fight off the two holding you.

"Easy young one," says yet another voice. "If you try to use your eyes too soon, there could be some damage that could be permanent."

The sound of this voice causes you to relax, and stop struggling.

"Alright," the voice says. "Let's get these revivers back to the Abbey. Dannflor and his crew are going to trade places with us. As for you who have just revived, I'm sure you know the drill, rest, eat up, and go to the places you feel comfortable, and that goes for those of you who aren't honest woodlanders as well."

"I just wonder about the one we've got Martin," says the person who blindfolded you. "I've seen most whom have lived, but I've never seen anyone like this one."

"Does it matter Brother Rafael?" asks Martin. "They still need food and rest, no matter whom they are."

Some time later, you were in a place that, from the sounds of the echos, was made of stone or brick. Then there were the smells of food cooking, which made your mouth water.

"Looks like you Warriors are always bringing in revivers just as I'm about to get food ready," says another voice.

"Nice to see you too, Friar Hugo," Martin says. "Be sure to bring some soup up to the Dormitories and the Infirmary."

"Who's going to the Infirmary and why?" asks a voice that seems to have some authority.

"It's this one right here Abbot," Martin says.

"Hmm, I see," says the Abbot. "I've never seen this one before."

"Part of the reason I'm taking them to the Infirmary," Martin says. "They also seem to be suffering from a concussion."

"Alright, carry on with what you were doing."

Some time later, you found yourself in a very comfy bed.

"Now this feels good," you say quietly. "Of course, it would be better if I could see."

You then hear a giggle. "I might be able to help you with that."

You then feel someone removing the cloth. A few layers of cloth later, you find yourself looking at the figure of a young woman.

"Would you like to remove the last piece off by yourself?" she asks.

"I wouldn't mind doing that," you say as you remove the last layer. However, the sight causes your eyes to bulge out. The young woman is a mouse with the hairstyle of a young woman. "Um, where am I?"

"Why, you're are Redwall," the mouse says. "And you are..."

"I'm (Fill in name)."


"Nice to meet you then," the mouse says. "I'm Sister Buttercup. Would you like to look in a mirror?"

"I wouldn't mind," you say.

She then gets out a small mirror and you take a good look at yourself. You are......

111.content:
You shift the mirror around, checking your visage from every angle to be sure that you face is intact. You breathe a sigh of relief. Despite a weird feeling accompanied by nausea and aches pulsing through your skull, there is nothing that needs plastic surgery. You glide a hand across your jawline, going up the cheek and running your fingers through your hairline. Your hand then drops down to feel your chest and ribs and despite the pain from before, there is no damage that can seen. Everything is in place. In fact, you're so glad that there is not a scratch on you that you just have to compliment yourself.

"Looking good," you smile to your reflection before handing the mirror back to the mouse. "I was expecting my face to be hamburger."

Sister Buttercup tilts her head quizzically, but smiles warmly as she takes the mirror and replaces it on the bedside table. "You must have suffered quite a shock to your head. Are you alright?"

"Yeah, I think so. Just feeling a little fuzzy and light up here," you tell her, putting your palms to your temples in emphasis, "like I've just lost my mind!"

The little mouse girl giggles when you squawk mirthfully. "It can sometimes happen that the injuries causing death will carry over to to a revival's new life. That is why you may be weak or in any pain after your revived," she explains to you with a concerned smile, adding, "--and why you may be dazed. I would venture to assume that you received quite a blow to the head?"

"Well, uh, yeah. Something like that. . ." you kind of drift off for a moment when she mentions something about death and revival, but seem to recall something involving a heavy impact. But death? You feel too. . .alive to be dead, everything seems to vivid to be death, or at least compared to your nebulous ideas of death, so you ask, " 'Causing death'? 'New life'? Are you saying I'm dead?"

"Well, you did die, yes, but have been revived in the nearby river. You are quite obviously a Dead Fan; surely this isn't the first time you have been revived, unless you. . ." the little mouse suddenly halts her explanation and places a paw over her maw, expression growing apologetic. "Unless you just died. Oh, I apologize, (your name here), I didn't mean to be insensitive."

"No need, little Sister," you assure the little mouse, "I figure I'm gonna be out of the loop for a while. In fact, now that I think about it, I'm surprised you're not overreacting to the difference in, uhm," you search for the words as your arms motion to you, Sister Buttercup and back, "species."

Put at ease by your chummy disposition, Buttercup explains, "I suppose it might be because Dead Fans will sometimes speak of their former lives as humans, but this is the first time a human has been brought to the abbey. Nevertheless, the mice at Redwall Abbey are sworn to care for travelers and revivers until they recover." She puts a clawed digit to her chin at she mulls a thought over. "Though, I suppose the abbots and abbesses will need to convene on the matter of your treatment after three days of your staying at Redwall."

"Hey, you make that sound as if I can expect a hazing," you accuse with a tongue in cheek, the facade of a piercing gaze falling when you imagine a throng of student's with paddles smacking you across the rear as you march to the other side of a room, and a smile cracks across your lips and you chuckle, "Ah, freshman year. Those were good days."

"Yes, well, that is simply a matter of business," she replies nonchalantly, "between Vermin and Woodlanders, each to their own and so forth. How we let them off helps revivers settle in to their roles. Until then, however," smiles kindly, "is there anything I can do to make yours a lovely stay at Redwall?"

You think over the kind little mouse's offer, scratching your head in thought. Your cheap wristwatch seems broken, maybe you could ask her for a sundial. The thing said waterproof to fifty yards and it couldn't handle. . .however deep is the Moss. Though being carried over here let you drip-dry a bit, your clothes are still soaking. Your shoes are completely logged, shirt and pants are clinging uncomfortably to your skin, and your underwear are beginning to chafe. Which gave you the idea.

"You wouldn't happen to have a spare pair of underwear, would you?" You look her up and down, noting the minimalistic outfit of a habit, white apron and bonnet. Maybe they don't even have undergarments, for all you know. ". . .Or does everyone 'go commando' around here?"

Sister Buttercup once again stares, completely lost as you wait for an answer. "I'm not sure---"

"Because I'm totally cool with that," you add with a thumbs up.

Her expression goes blank for a moment before she shakes her head, "I will see what I can arrange for you." And with that, the little mouse hurries off.

Once Buttercup disappears around the doorway, you lie back and stretch your arms and legs out, way over the head and foot of the bead, your frame clearly too tall for the frame made for critters slightly bigger than a mouse. Popping your neck some with a twist to the left and a twist to the right to get that kink out gets you feeling much better already. You let your limbs fall down limply over the sides of the bed while you get to thinking that some shut-eye might not be such a bad idea right now.

1112.content:
You take a moment of pause to close your eyes, enjoy a good scratch on the crotch and toss about the bed, but when you can't get comfortable you bolt upwards and swing your feet to the floor. "Nah, forget it. I'm at Redwall. The Redwall," you say to yourself as you look around the spacious infirmary. "Should at least check out more than one room before moving on, right?"

Vaguely, you recall the multitude of times that Redwall's infirmary was described in the books and it looks about right with two rows of beds set up against the walls. Open windows let the let shine in and the fresh air flows through the muggy room with every passing breeze. And you were not the only one dragged in from the river, so it seems. Several bodies apart from your own occupy the beds, some more restful than others, but none of them seem to have given you any mind. Yet. You spy a doorway at the far end of the room and make your way towards it, moving past the sleeping figures bundled up in their covers, and wave enthusiastically to those who stare look at you in confusion. One thing that catches your eye is a cloth of a purple and red diamond pattern that is draped over the bedposts.

"I'd know that harlequin getup any day. Slagar!" you exclaim loudly enough to make the other stir as you lean over the foot of the bed. The head pressed against the pillow turns over as the red fox's eyes squint against the light trying to focus on you. "So cunning, so shrewd," you continue to comment , "a villain so, ehhh, by the books, shall we say? But I guess that's why you were easily identifiable." You grin as you absentmindedly flick one of his toe claws peeking out from under the covers and they recoil away. "Tell me, what'cha doing back in Redwall? Did the abbot turn a blind eye to you, again?"

Slagar raises his paws from under the covers and rubs them over his face. You notice that it is free from the scarring that his signature hood was intended to conceal. He releases a growl from his throat as he groans out, "Ambushed by the Long Patrol, I am pitied by the Redwall mice once more, and now, am I to be haunted by this revolting wretch?"

You purse your lips at his insult and fire back, "You're one to talk. Last I remember, you looked like a fox who took a hot clothes iron to the face. What happened Slaggy? Got a little lift-and-tuck in your downtime . . . at the bottom of the well?" You snicker as you see the fox's face twist through a phase of being shaken moving onto anger and then a sudden exuberance as his paws shoot out for your throat in a second.

You try to speak, but your words come out in a gurgle and completely incoherent. "Aaakk! Thesh eshcalerted v'rry qwerklr."

Augh! This escalated very quickly.

Despite any misgivings you might have had about the fox and his condition, Slagar's grip proves to be solid as your own hands close on his wrists to pry his enraged fingers loose while they cut off your air supply. Strangely enough, while your struggling with that, eyes bugging out with the unpleasantness of it all, you do not lose consciousness. The scene drags on for a good minute and Slagar is pinning you down, getting a few swipes in with his right paw, and you still clock him square behind the jaw hard enough to topple him sideways. The fox's paw releases your throat

"Damn!" you exclaim, sitting up. "You had me going for a moment there! I mean, you went all Boston Strangler on me when I thought you'd be, blaaaaugh, all comatose like---". You are cut off when the fox launches at you again, knocking the wind out of you as you yelp loudly. Once again you are not winded as the scuffle continues to rage between the pair of beds. Now the attention of the other critters awake enough to see whats going on has been shifted to fight that is increasing in intensity, curses and insults flying, slaps and punches landing, pained groans and girly screeches ringing out.

Having had enough, you decide that a dignified retreat is in order. You scramble under the nearest bed, huffing and gasping from the exhaustion, covered in nasty scratches and fox wounds. Trying to pull yourself up on the other side is caught short by Slagar grabbing you by your feet, prompting another surprised yowl from you. Looking around, you spot a shrew looking groggily at your from the bed ahead of you.

"No! Ya gotta help me!" you implore as you scratch at the stone floor for traction. "That meanie fights dirty! He bites and scraaaa-tches! No-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o!" Your wails land on deaf ears as your are pulled back under, finger nails scraping at the ground.

"What's all this commotion I'm hearin' all the way from the hall?" A voice interrupts Slagar as something jabs him hard in the ribs. He halts his attempts to turn you spinal column into an accordion as the current caretaker of the infirmary confronts the recently revived fox. Sister Sloey confronts Slagar with naught but a wooden spoon to branding before his nose. "There will be no fightin' within these walls."

"Quiet, mouse." Slagar says hoarsely, the scuffle with you draining much energy from his already weakened state. "The newcomer needs to be taught a lesson in humility. The sooner he learns his pla-AAH!"

You on the other hand decide that you were not out of it just yet. Springing back in with a second wind, you pick up a diminutive nightstand and smash it violently into the distracted fox's head for a decisive victory. The fox flies forward quite a ways, forcing little Sloey to spring desperately out of the way as he crashes to the ground for the K.O..

"Aww yeah, and it's a home run to the left field! Red fox; corner pocket!" You raise your fists and pace back and forth before the downed fox while spouting sports goals to add insult to injury. The shocked mouse that you barely acknowledge bolts out, calling for assistance. "All hail to the mighty mountain of man that is (your name)."

You curtail your victory babble as you eye the fox crumpled on the floor. "Hay, Slagar, you just unconscious, or are your dead?" You as while rolling him over. He doesn't seem to be breathing, and your not one to check for a pulse or anything. Maybe the way one eyelid is open more than the other and the tongue hanging out, the worst should be assumed. "He might be dead," you muse. "But," you consider all details, including the fact that you're still holding your breath from the excitement of the fight, deciding that things are not all what they seem, "I'll give him the benefit of the doubt."

Rather unceremoniously hauling Slagar back to the bed by his tail, you heave him back up, plant him face first in his pillow, body falling pretty much prone eagle except for one arm hanging off the side. Now he looked like someone hung over after downing five four-ohs the previous night. Adding the final touch by yanking the covers across to him land mostly on his upper half completes the look of a sleeping frat boy. And you congratulate yourself. "Sleep tight."

"Now where was I?" you ponder, scratching your chin. "Oh, right! Let's hit the abbey."

You start for the door once again, getting only a few paces away from seeing the chamber beyond when something moves into your way. It's a figure, tall, robust and imposing. She is feminine in build and in her attire. When her eyes meet yours and glare down daggers back into your sockets, your mind seems to click a connection in. You don't know how you know, but you immediately identify the badger as Constance from the first two books.

"Oh, why, Sloey?," you whine at the mouse standing behind the mountain of black and white. "You two aren't ever in the same book together and you send in the most ornery badger to grace Redwall?" The comment comes out as a question from your incredulity.

"Listen here, Dead Fan, Redwall Abbey is a grounds for peace and healing when it comes to you revivers," the badger mother footsteps thunder as she approaches you. "Your strange talk, your foul temper won't sit well with us Redwallers, nor with any other goodbeasts. The vermin are likely to shred you to ribbons the moment you open your uncouth gob. Perhaps a few more murders on your soul would help you settle down. I'm sure the abbey council would not forgo throwing a reviver as troublesome as you right over the walls. So it's your choice Dead Fan," she menaces, teeth baring as she points a claw to your vacated bed, "abide the abbey or shove off!"

"Okay, maybe Cregga was worse," you concede as you back away from the advancing badger mother, "but I still didn't like you."

Her deepening growl and flexing claws say that you better make a choice, quick.

"Hmm," you look heavenward to the left, "behave myself and probably get chaperoned for the rest of my stay at Redwall." Your eyes shift right as you continue to ponder, "I could make a tactical retreat, making things worse for myself. Or I could.. .. . . .. . "

1321.content:
You blink, and then blink again several more times in surprise. The face looking back at you through the small mirror is mostly a long snout, tipped with a pink nose, and with a pair of slightly beady black eyes appearing where it widens to accommodate your head. Any fine facial details are covered by a short layer of dark-brown fur, which covers most of your body except your pink-tinged tail, which you are only now aware you're twitching animatedly in surprise, and your long hands.

"What on earth happened?" You mutter, lightly tugging one of your whiskers, fascinated by the new feeling. Sister Buttercup overhears, and thinks you're talking to her.

"Well, something happened to you first. You seem a bit dazed, so something or somebody probably hit you over the head pretty hard. After that, you, uh, you died. Then you floated up in the river near the Abby, and, as mice of the order of Redwall, its our sworn duty to look after you until you recover."

"Oh." Still feeling dazed, you just keep up the conversation, despite a few key words clamoring for acknowledgement in the back of your mind, you're too over-awed to keep track of much of anything. "What happens then?"

         She hesitates for a few seconds, as if reluctant to tell you. "As a rat, and probably a wrongdoer, there's a good chance some of our warriors will put you out on the road, once you're well enough, of course, and from there you can go wherever you like. "

         Realizing you may soon be kicked from the abbey jolts you into a full reclamation of your faculties. "What? But I'm no vermin-I've never killed in my life! Please, can't I stay here?"

         The Sister looks at you sadly. "I don't know. Usually, we've gotten nothing but a few hard lessons from letting vermin, er, your kind, stay in the Abbey after we revive them. But, you do seem a bit different than the norm. Most of the villains we drag from the river are more than a little rougher than you, and you just seem...Different. I can't put my paw on it, but I'll tell the elders that you don't want to go, and I'll put in a good word for you. In the mean time, if you're serious about staying, you'll probably have to be moved to the cellar when you're feeling better, in case you're simply trying to steel something or get up to something else like that." You nod, suddenly feeling quite tired. As you rapidly fall asleep, the last conscious thought that buzzes in your mind and strikes you is only one word.

Redwall!

13212.content:
Sometime later, you are glumly being marched out of Redwall's massive main gate in the company of several brawny otters, all well armed with javelins and long cloth slings. Keeping you hemmed in but otherwise ignoring you as they chat to each other, they escort you far down the path.

         "Right, mates," A hulking male with an eye-patch booms. "I think we've gone far enough with this one. Now listen up, rat. We're civil beasts at Redwall, so we'll give you food for three days, if you don't wolf it all down right away. After that, you can go where you like and do what you like, just not back to the Abbey. We're not about to give you a weapon, as you're as likely to attack us the moment we turn our backs as try to, say, go fishing with it." He unceremoniously thrusts a small pouch at you, and then turns to to his fellow riverdogs. "Come on, mates. Somebody pulled Balisses' head out of the drink earlier, and they want every able-bodied beast there when they go to loose 'im."

         A younger otter shudders at the sibilant name, falling into line with his fellows. "That great ol' serpent? Hunh, I would've just tossed him back in the soup if I'd been the lucky one to find him." Talking among themselves of the massive, feared, blind adder, they jog back the way they had come, rounding a bend and starting the back down the long walk to Redwall.

         You sigh despairingly, looking down the path in the other direction. While you knew that this was probably some kind of dream brought on by the accident, and you'd be around in no time in a hospital somewhere, it still seemed a cruel joke by Dame Fortune to land you in one of your favorite fantasy world as a universally disliked villain. By all appearances, the question now was; 'now what?'

          Off to your right stretched the 'flat'lands, slowly rolling hills that stretched to the horizon in a sea of grass. You think you can make out a few short little points in the distance, possibly mountains, and another, bigger one back towards to the north. You seem to faintly recall something about a huge tribe of pygmy shrews living down that way, maybe they'd be more accepting than the Redwallers? You don't give yourself time to enjoy the irony in that thought as you sweep your gaze back to the left.

          On the other hand, the left side of the path gives way to thick forest, and you can't see very deep into the brush; who knew what could be waiting in there? There certainty could be greater opportunities to find food, once your supplies run out.

         And finally, there's the broad, dusty path that runs down for ages, until it's lost in the green of a copse growing on the 'flatlands' side of the road. Maybe you could head south, and then... Just see where it took you. You had already seen in person that death was a stranger in this world, so knew you didn't have to worry about much.
13212.title: Freedom of choice...Is sometimes overrated.

132122.content:
Reasoning that you could cut to the right or left at any time if it suited you, and simply curious as to what awaited farther down the path, you start walking, footpaws stamping the dust. As you walk on this way, you try to remember which direction from Redwall the old St. Ninian's church was located; you seem to recall it being in the opposite direction. Oh well.

         Travelling down a surprisingly well-maintained road, you should be able to travel quickly. You might eventually reach the Great Plateau, then the desert, the South Steppes and wastelands, and finally; Southsward, for all you know!

         The knowledge that the universe of Redwall is yours to explore dredges up burgeoning euphoria in you; the fact that there seems to be little real danger in this world not doing anything to stifle it. You feel flushed with a sense of opportunity, and unconsciously increase your pace, wondering how to take advantage of this peculiar situation. The Redwallers had been attacked countless times before by vermin, including many rats. They had every right save what their reputation suggested to be leery of keeping them around. Perhaps when others saw you meant them no harm, they might be a bit more accepting. There were certainly many friendly enough tribes and groups spread throughout the Redwall world. Maybe you could join one?

         Your happy feeling remains as you cross another bend in the path, and walk bang into-

1321221.content:
The big, matted-furred vermin stays on his feet after you collide, which is more than can be said of you. You land heavily on the road with a grunt and a small cloud of dust. You stare up in alarmed surprise as a dozen other vermin, at least six rats, a few weasels, a couple of stoats, and a ferret or two, move to surround you. "What 'ave we here, boys? Anothe' lazy little pup wot thinks he can go bludering intu' whoever eh wants, eh?" The rodent you jostled punches out, catching you in the side of your snout. With another grunt, your head snaps to the side, and the big rat gestures to one of his fellows with a long, rusty spike.

         "Dirtfur, get this liddle worm in the ranks. The Cheif'll be 'specting us back at camp soon!"

         "Aye, Capt. Mangetail." A weasel with a filthy coat roughly hauls you up and manhandles past the 'Capt' and into the large crowd you can now see milling about behind him.

         There are vermin of all varieties, seeming to vary in mood between dejection and enthusiasm, and surrounded by a loose formation of well armed rat soldiers waering crude uniforms.

         Orders are bellowed, and the entire group, swings back around and into the trees. Nervously, you glance at a younger weasel in line beside you, looking about as worried as you feel. "What's happening? Where are we going?" You ask, whispering for fear of drawing one of the rat's attention.

"Dunno, mate. Name's Grigtail. I was jess out lookin' for food along the path one day. When this gang comes by and tells me its my lucky day, that I git to join the army of a mighty warlord. They threw me intu' line, and we've been marchin' all day, but I don't know where they's taking us."

"Quiet back there!" Barks one of the rats, lashing out with a spear butt. You and Grigtail fall silent, as you continue tramping through the brush for some time, stung by insects, slapped by branches, and occasionally whacked at by the irate recruiting vermin. Tired, thirsty, and sweaty, but thankfully having not been stripped of your provisions, you eventually arrive at

You gulped at the sight- out of all of the villains in the books, Cluny the Scourge had been one of the most cunning foes that Redwall had faced. Even Matthias had been unable to best him in battle- his slaying had only come because of the Joseph Bell falling on top of him. Cluny had used many strategies during his siege of the Abbey- tower, tunneling, battering ram, and a few more. In the end, it had taken the capture of a dormouse's family to provide him with the means of entering the place, when the head of the family was forced to betray Redwall in an attempt to rescue them.

Cluny then began to walk among the various vermin, swishing his long, and barbed, tail. "Well, it seems some of you once followed me," he said as he stopped in front of one particular rat. "Ah Redtooth, my old friend. Been a while since water's passed between us."

"That it has Chief," the rat said with a slight smile.

"Would you like your old job back?" Cluny asked.

"If you'll have me," Redtooth said, with a slight bow. "I promise to serve you as faithfully as I did before my previous death by that mangy cat, Ungatt Trunn."

"Good," Cluny said, clasping a paw on Redtooth's shoulder. "Go inside- I'm sure some of the others will recognize you from before. If not, you know what to do."

"Yes sir," Redtooth said as he straightened up. He then marched into the church. Sounds of fighting soon entered your ears.

Cluny then stepped in front you and Grigtail, and slowly looked you over. Then he...

The massive rat, wearing a cloak of black bat-wings and a helm crowned with the horns of some monster insect, paces past you. You stiffen and shrink back slightly, against the unyielding bodies of the recruits in position behind you. As if smelling a slightly abnormal amount of fear, The Warlord suddenly stops.

         "You there, rat," He growls, motioning at you with his left hand, the other idly swishing his tail. "Step forward." He presses a coil of his whip-like tail up against your throat, hindering your breathing even as he transfixes you with his eye. "Ever been in a battle before, worm? Think I could use you in my army?" He growls. " You don't look like much-But how 'bout the rest of you lot, eh?" He nods at the greater bulk of vermin assembled behind and around you.

          Several of the larger, more ferocious looking specimens begin to nod enthusiastically. "You all look like you'ves notched your blades more'n a few times. Like you could handle yourselves ina scrap. Well, we'll soon see about that, me cullies. -DEFEND YOURSELVES!" Without warning, he crashes into you, knocking you over and staggering over fully half a dozen other vermin. Winded, you instinctively roll out of the way as Cluny lays about with his tail at any target in reach, pounding with his impressive fists, even biting and clawing when opportunity arises. Rats and weasels, stoats and ferrets, cry out and scramble ineffectually to get out of the way, too disorientated to offer resistance of any real sort.

         The God of War stops his rampage after only a few brief moments, standing in the center of his downed would-be soldiers. He doesn't have a mark on him, cape hardly even ruffled, but most of the vermin in his near vicinity lie curled on the ground, nursing torn ears and badly bruised bodies. Those farther out simply stare at him in awe, not moving in case they should incite another show of his ferocity. "Just as I thought." He spits scornfully at a hulking weasel squirming in the mud at his feet, occupied in alternately pawing at his battered jaw and flogged back. "You're all rotten. Worthless. Incapable altogether of harming even a single, unarmed foe. But I can make you better. You are mine 'tilI death and beyond if I wish it. -But I can turn you into an army of the greatest warriors ever seen in this land, or any other! Foes will tremble at your name, and gold and slaves beyond imagination shall be yours. All you desire- all you could desire- shall be yours. That is, if you remember your Master...WHO DO YOU SERVE?!"

         Any vermin not groaning on the ground don't hesitate. They know the only answer, as if they'd been through it all before. With the way death worked around here, maybe they had.
"Cluny! Cluny! Cluny the Scourge!"
1321221111.title: One Master.

choices: The march to the periphery of the Hall is hard, but uneventful.
You are intercepted by another force, but whether allies or enemies....
13212211111.content:
Cluny swaggers off, barking orders to his captains. "Grimeclaw, issue proper 'tools' to these boys. Cheesethief, make sure all recruiter and forager groups are back in. Scrag, attend me in the command tent! Now!"
He marches out of sight around the church, a large, neatly-uniformed weasel hurrying to catch up.

         Several rats begin doling out weapons, namely long, rusty spikes that look like they might have once been members of the segments of fencing edging the church grounds, cloth slings, and crude spears. You pick up your weapon, an ill-kept but sharp ax that looked like it had been looted or stolen from an unfortunate, now long deceased wood-worker. "Just what I am supposed to do with this? I couldn't separate a skinny limb from an oaktree with it!"

         Grigtail shrugs, striking an valorous pose with his new long scythe. "Bah. Cheer up, mate! We're in the army now! A few seasons of marchin' an' fightin', and we'll all be livin' like kings 'afore you know it proper!" He punctuates the last statement by elaborately flourishing his polearm, dropping it and nearly taking off your tail. "Whoopsy. Sorry, mate. I'm not used to these things either. Dey call 'em 'pikes', just like after the streamwolves, right?"

         You nod, not bothering to correct the weasel, and glumly wondering at your prospects should you get into a battle. Movement all around catches your eye, and you realize the vermin are congregating by a small dais off to the side. Captain Mangetail berates a few others into moving, and notices you standing apart from the rest.

         "Ahoy, you two there! Aye, you! The Chief'll be making his address soon! Get into line! Now!" Dragging Grigtail behind you, you hurriedly saddle over to the crowd. The Warlord now bears a long pike rammed through a bleached mole skull, and his tail barb glistens with deadly venom.

         "Listen up, you whelps! There's a better harbor 'ere abouts than this slimy pit. An underground fortress built by an ancient clan of magic badgers, called 'Brock Hall'. We're going to take it. From there, we can march on any target and never fear a counter attack. From there, we can maintain a war of any length with Redwall. Eventually, we will wear them down. And the greatest fortress in the land -will be ours!"

         The horde cheers at the mention of hated and coveted Redwall Abbey, infamous for repulsing nearly any other conqueror. Cluny was the sole keeper of that title, and his desire to fully regain ownership of the magnificent sandstone abbey was legendary. And now he apparently felt his strength might just be great enough to re-join the war, especially with a well-supplied and easily defended base to wage it from.

         More commands are issued, and soon the army is formed into rough formation and begins tramping down the dusty path, from there to cut into the woods after a ways and swing to the south and east. Drums beat out a rapid, monotonous marching rhythm, and standards and pennants topped with grisly trophies blow in the wind ominously.
13212211111.title: The army prepares to march!

choices: Well-maintained feilds leading to a stout pallisade.
A small door set in the lower boughs of a tree.
132122111111.content:
The horde marches hard for some time, turning off the path and onto the flatlands to avoid being seen by one of the patrols of Sparra Warriors that frequently flew patrols above the woodlands around the Abbey. Curses fly and officers crack whips as you negotiate the large trench with difficulty, a large team of rats bearing a heavy battering ram particularly hampered.

         Glancing at the huge, well-worn thing, you try to recall everything you know about Brockhall, and wonder if it might be over-kill. The place wasn't that big; certainly not a great fortress like Redwall. It was an ancestral home of an ancient tribe of badgers, far older than the Abbey, possibly older than the late fortress Kotir. It has served as a base for the group of resistance fighters called the Corim, and was the birth place of numerous famed badger warriors. After the establishment of Redwall, it had eventually been abandoned, and taken over by a nest of serpents, who had fought with a vermin expedition from the far north, and were eventually slain themselves by a small force of Redwallers. No attempt to re-colonize it was made, and generations later, it was occupied by the vermin army known as the Ravagers, who had been driven out by Redwallers as well.

         Given the timeless nature of this place in relation to the book-series you had read, there was no telling who controlled it now. As long as it wasn't badgers. You think, remembering the way their size, ferocity, and skill had been described, and hoping that you'd never be on the wrong end of their great weapons. It occurs to you to ask a native what they know of the place. "Hay, Grigtail, who's in control of the Hall right now?"

         He shrugs, looking unfocused as he watches his feet carefully to help discourage stumbling. "Dunno. Heard it was Raga Bol's gang o' bullies who had it last, but that place changes hands more often than a gem in a crowd of Gonfellin mice. Could be anybody by now."

         You nod, about to question him further, but instead jump in the air and yelp as something snaps you in the ear-tip with enough precision to draw blood. Gritting your teeth in pain, you look to where Mangetail holds his whip aloft threateningly.

         "Silence in the ranks there, or I'll give you another few licks with my leather beauty here!" He snarls, and you don't respond, just hunch in your shoulders instinctively to make yourself a smaller target, and go back to marching in relative quiet, entertaining images of the captain with your ax protruding from the front of his snout.

         When Cluny deems the army to be far enough from the Abbey without alerting possible reinforcements, you swing about and begin to punch your way through the dense woodland. Order is difficult to maintain with tree-trunks to swerve around, logs to climb over, and brackets to cut through, and mosquitoes harry you insistently, but at least the captains can't aim their disciplinary tools as well, though not for lack of trying.

          The slog keeps your mind off the impending battle, and you are startled as orders to halt are bellowed loudly, and you catch your first glimpse of Brockhall.
132122111111.title: Is it still properly 'Brockhall' now?

1321221111112.content:
The foliage thins out dramatically ahead, leading up to the trunk of a massive deciduous tree. The tree's canopy was apparently thick enough to block out light from above, resulting in it being surrounded by the large clearing. Tucked away at the base of the trunk, in a hollow surrounded by several huge, protruding roots, rests an innocuous door, the only thing suggesting that the great tree was anything other than another impressive forest giant.

         "Division halt! You six, get up there and make sure we're not disturbing anybody's precious tea-time." Captain Mangetail gestures to you, Grigtail, and several other Troops in your row, and you dutifully start making your way across the field to the door. Up close, it seems almost a bit sinister, a small, unmarked portal nestled in between piles of dead leaves. You look for the doorknob, and notice that door isn't completely untouched as you go to yank it open.

         There are an abundance of small scratch-marks, as if somebeast had desperately tried to get in in a hurry. You pause and lean down to examine them, but are interrupted by a scarred, jet-black fox. "Well, aren't you going to open it sometime today?" He growls, spitting irritatingly close to your foot-paw.

         Your still-sore ear throbs painfully, but you glance at his impressive collection of war wounds and decide to keep your mouth shut, giving the knob a hard tug instead. It creeks, but otherwise doesn't budge; the tree must have warped the frame as it grew. Grigtail gives you a hand, and after some straining, you wrench it open.

          A blast of some musky, foul smell pours out, setting your fur on end with its cloying scent. A flight of crude steps cut out of the earth lead steeply down into darkness. "Er, why don't you go first, Jubbra?" A small, golden furred rat that looked like a mouse- or vice-versa- pipes up from behind you, fiddling with a long dagger. A hulking ferret who had been standing next to him shoulders the fox out of the way to get to the stairs.

          "Duh? You got it, Aze-Kame. Phooey! The smell that these badger 'oles have -makes you think of a serpent's rotting carcass at noontide in mid-summer!"

         "Well ain't that poetic." Grumbles a rat from behind you as you reluctantly follow Jubbra down the stairs.


         You carefully descend on the ladder-like protrusions, the musky smell growing stronger and the light from the door above seemingly being devoured by the darkness before accomplishing much.

         "I don't suppose anybody brought a light? I can't see mah' paw in front of my face." Complains the same rat who had rebuked Jubbra's metaphor.

         "I gotta flint." Says Grig, his voice rebounding and echoing surprisingly well through the stifling dark, audible for several moments afterwards.

         "Keep it down, will ya'?! Or I'll put my hatchet through the back o' your thick skull. Maybe that'll shut yew up!" Snarls the black fox from the rear of the group, waving a short, elaborate ax for emphasis.

         "Ah, shud-up you stuffy old bushtail! There ain't nobeast here anyways. What're you scared of? The dark or something?"

"No-beast talks to Thorn-claws Oak-Breaker like that!" He yelps, trying to clamber over both you and the other rat to get at Grigtail.

         "Duh, looks like this is the bottom guys." Grunts Jubbra. Shielding yourself from the crazed fox with the haft of your ax, you step out- and tumble down face first, the other rat and Oak-Breaker landing on top of you in a heap.

"Eh, wot? Uh, there's a step there."

"Hold on, I found an old torch-bracket." Calls Grigtail from off to the side, and light reveals the dusty chamber as he puts his flint to use. Cobwebs dominate everywhere, sticking between old furniture and roots hanging from the ceiling. A closed door is set into the wall off to the right, near to where Grigtail found an unused torch, and the chamber divides up ahead. Down here, the sickly-sweet smell is almost painfully strong.

         You clamber back to your paws, dusting yourself off. Breaker doesn't say anything, and it occurs to you that the fall might have briefly stunned him. Finally, some luck. You think, looking for another torch to put to light. Farther down the tunnel, Jubbra's already done so, quietly chatting with the blonde rat you now were beginning to suspect might be a jerbilrat from the distant south as they both explore father down.

Blowing the dirt off of an old table, you slowly turn to the weasel. "Looks like you were right, Grigtail. This place is empty as a tomb."

         That idea is contested from the deep-voiced scream that materializes from down the tunnel. The torch that had marked where Jubbra and the jerbilrat he had called Aze-Kame were flickers violently and goes out.

"That sounds like Jubbra!" You grip your axe tightly, staring down the tunnel, in time to see Aze-Kame bolting towards you as if there were a pack of rabid wolverines chasing him. He runs smack into Breaker just as the fox rises to his feet, and falls down, babbling incoherently.

"Calm down! Where's Jubbra? What happened?" Asks the complainative rat, slapping Aze on the head to get him to pay attention.

"G-g-gone! It's s-s-snakes!" Squeaks Kame, words almost inaudible from the rustling and hissing that emerges from the darkness ahead, just beyond the flickering torch light. A set of pale eyes reflect in the light-and then another, and another. Hissing fills the air, as well as a fresh wave of deathly sweetness.

"Quick, you idiots! This way!" Howls Braker, bolting for the nearest exit-the door to Grigtail's immediate right. Not about to argue, you grab Aze-Kame by the scruff of his neck and race after.
1321221111112.title: Why is it always...

choices: And at the end of the tunnel lies...
13212211111121.content:
You pelt through the doorway, looking about wildly for the next escape route. Aze-Kame voices your immediate thoughts as you take in the chamber.

         "We're trapped! They's gonna eat us!" He howls, running in circles.

         "Not me! Not now! -Now pass me a bench or something, you idiots!" Yelps Breaker from the door, back braced against it, paws digging trenches in the dirt floor as it's hammered form beyond. Realizing that barricading it shut may be your only hope, you snatch hold of a solid table and drag it to the door with the strength and speed only acquired through panic, the others falling suit with their own furnishings .

         The reincarnation rule was small comfort when cornered in an underground ruin by a pack of giant adders.

         Breaker jumps to the left as you upend the table against the door, then help Aze and the other rat prop a short bench against it. The door groans and shudders as the giant snakes ram it repeatedly, starting to work it's way open.

         "Blast it! There's no more tables!" The other rat calls, scrabbling against the far wall. You spin back to the door as a particularily enthusiastic bang hits it. A pale, slit pupiled eye is visible in the crack between the door and jamb for a moment.

         "Hold on, small onessss. Soon Zassalisss will come to show you ...eternity." A sibilant voice hisses, and then the banging resumes two-fold. You back away, holding onto your axe for comfort, as the jirbilrat and the fox also grip their weapons and move away from the door as it starts to creek and splinter under the punishment.

         "Well, Grig, I guess this is good-bye for now." You gulp, looking for your companion. "Grig?"

         "We're in here mates!" His voice calls from the thin-air to your left. You can still see a small amount of the glow from his torch, but can't make out exactly where it comes form.

         "What?"

         "Oh, for the love of Jacques!" His arm emerges from the wall, latches onto a befuddled Breaker, and hauls him in, followed by Aze-Kame and finally you.

         To your surprise, a long stone cave surrounds you, which you realize connects to the main cavern by a narrow crevice at an angle that makes it almost impossible to see from the outside. The ohter rat holds a finger to his snout and starts to slowly pad down to the left -just as the door breaks in with the screech of splintered wood.

         Aggravated hissing from multiple throats sounds, but the serpents can't seem to find your escape route.

         Deciding not to push your luck, you stifle your survival instinct and softly follow after Grig and the rat who's name you have yet to hear, Aze-Kame and Breaker bringing up the rear.
13212211111121.title: ...Snakes.

choices: You were correct, and reach the other side safely enough.
132122111111211.content:
The tunnel is cold, barren stone, dark and damp. At least it isn't cramped, and the lack of dirt walls banish most questions about its ability to stand up.

         You walk in silence for quite a ways, eventually speeding up to a less cautious jog. Grigtail stops abruptly after only a few moments, and you almost knock him over before you can slow down.

         "Oi! Careful! I almost dropped the torch."

         "What's the hold-up for? We gotta get out of here."

         "There's a big pool in front of us."

         "What?" You come out from around him and examine the tunnel ahead. The torchlight glitters of a number of small waves disturbed by Grigtail's foot-paw, which slowly swoosh beyond your vision and return the pool to it's primeval quietude.

"Of all things- getting chased out of the Snakeden only to be drowned in an underground lake. It prob'ly goes down and down forever." Groans the rat.


         There is some shared muttering from Aze-kame and Breaker, and they both turn to him.

"Moron! Of all the place's you could've led us--now we're either gonna sit in here until we die of old age, or drown!" Snarled the fox, raising his axe.

"That's some gratitude for yuh! You'd all be in another life if it weren’t for me, Addon Blackfoot!"

"Better there than sitting around in here forever, filth-fur!"

"Why you-" Addon pulls out a sharpened pickaxe and hefts it threateningly, as Breaker drops into a crouch, growling.


         Deciding not to let them get carried away and possibly have the echoes alerting the snakes, you come between them.

         "Cool it, you two! I think I read about this place; the water's only waist deep at most, and doesn’t go on for more than forty feet at most." To prove your confidence, you turn and boldly start into the cold water, holding up your weapon above the surface to keep it from rusting still further.

"Well, aren't you lot coming? Can you at least give me the torch, Grig? I don't wanna be here when it gets dark."

The reminder that the only light source would soon go out prompts the others to back off and reluctantly follow you, with an obviously reluctant Aze-Kame getting in at the rear and frantically trying to keep as much of himself as possible above the liquid.
132122111111211.title: And at the mid-point of the tunnel lies...

choices: "Blackfoot's right; we should get back to the main force soon."
"I've had enough getting chased by snakes. I think we should stay here."
1321221111112111.content:
Your assertions are revealed to be correct; the water isn't any more than waist deep on you or any of the others, save Aze-Kame, who makes a series of odd-squeaking noises as it eventually comes up nearly to his chest, at least until Breaker roughly tells him to be quiet.

         Grigtail speaks up from behind you as you all wade through the gloom, weapons held high.

"So, how did you know this thing wasn't an underground lake or somethin'? And I've heard stories of huge old eels and worse that swum in to dark holes like these when the world was young, and grew so big that they'd break the sky and burn themselves on the sun, if they e’er come out, so they never do. How'd you know there wasn't one of those in here?"

"I think it's a bit shallow for them, at any rate. And I’d read about this place in a book once. It described this whole tunnel and part of Brockhall. It even mentions how the other way is a dead-end, this water, and the way out."

"So, just where does this thing come out, then?"

"At the edge of a river or water meadow, I think. I remember it splits up ahead, and if we take the left fork, we should get out before long."

" 'Tis a darn good thing you knew how to read; I never bothered to learn myself. Didn't think it would come in useful."

"Maybe I can teach you sometime -and oh, look, we're here."


         At the mention that you were leaving the pool, Aze races past you and jumps out onto the bank, shaking himself vigorously and shuddering. Confidant in your ability to recall the directions, you lead on, the tunnel following the directions you had predicted. In almost no time, you see an enormously welcome glow ahead, and race out of the tunnel.


          It opens onto a small river flowing through the trees, the tunnel mouth leading out of what might have been the high-water bank in flood season. Addon starts to fill up a flask from the river, while Breaker gratefully leans against a tree nearby.

"Erg. I'm not going underground again as long as I incarnate. Tunnels is for the moles!"

"You said it, mate!" Calls Aze, from where he was lying on a sandy beach a ways form the water, drying off.

"Does anybody know the way back to camp from here? Cluny won't be happy if we're tardy with our report." You call, looking back at the tree line.

"Cluny? Who cares about Cluny? I never really liked him, anyways. Right now, if he sent anybody in after us, he definitely thinks of us as K-I-A. Right now, we're our own masters. And I have more than half a mind to just lie here on this beach for a while." Snorts Breaker, moving down the beach a little ways past Aze and plopping down. Addon, on the other hand, shakes his bottle to make sure it's full, and comes over to you.

"I don't like Mr. Scourge, either, mates, but what about food? Cluny alwa's kept his army fed, and I sure don't see many fruit trees around here."

"Ah, we'll think of something. It can't be that hard to find vittles in these woods."

"You'd be surprised."

'Whatever. I had enough of followin' orders in the few weeks I spent with Cluny before getting tossed into that there snake-den. I ain't going back now."

You look back and forth between them as they argue, finally saying:
1321221111112111.title: You were correct, and reach the other side safely

13212211111121111.content:
"An' jus' who asked you, eh?" Breaker growls, sitting up now as you mention your decision, pawing his axe.

         "Calm down. You don't have to come. What about you, Grigtail?"

         "I'd o' thought that I'd hate having to march and fight and get chased by snakes all day... But now that it's over, that was kinda’ fun. And Cluny will probably reward us if'n we report back to him what's inside of Brockhall, smart-like. And besoides; we all know what happens to Deserters."

         Breaker gets fully up and prowls towards you, swinging his axe, followed by an anxious looking Kame.

         "An' that's why I don't want yous going back, either. If Cluny knows I'm not dead, that's what I'll become-a Deserter. And I don't want to have to be hiding in every hole 'twixt here and the Southern Gorge 'cause that overgrown rat decided to send a hunting party aft'ah me!"

         "Relax. If he asks- which, since yous ain't nuttin' but another piece of pike-fodder, is hardly likely-we'll tell him you got dragged off by the snakes after they took Jubbra, and we don't have a clue wot happened to you after that. Happy?" Asks Addon impatiently.

         Breaker considers for a few moments, shifting his weight between his foot paws. At length, he gives you an accepting nod.
"Fine then. But ifn I get skinned alive after one of his pet trackers get's me trail, I'm gonna come back for yus. And you're gonna hurt. You can bet on that like the sun coming up on the 'morrow."

         "Fair enough. Happy trails," As Breaker strides off down the sandy river bank with an appearance of finality, Addon hefts his pickaxe and turns to you and Grig. "Now, dose ei'er of yous know the way back to camp?"

         "I know." Pipes up Aze-Kame from behind you. "That tunnel twisted and turned quite a bit, but I think it's back in that direction, over that ridge there. The big rocky one that you can jus' see through the trees from here. If we head for the big oak tree growing off'n it, we're bound to make camp afore dark."

         "Great. Let's rest a bit mates and then move out."
13212211111121111.title: True blue an' never make-a-break for the hills.

choices: You demonstrate you loyalty by undergoing a long march back with important info.
He's not interested in hearing your crazy stories.
132122111111211111.content:
It turns out the Jirbil Rat was more right than even he thought. The huge oak tree actually grows out of the woodland behind the ridge, and just so happens to be the marker for Brockhall. After the break you took, your provisions that you received at Redwall are depleted, and night is falling. Ahead several lights shine through the trees, accompanying the sounds made only by several hundred vermin.

         You rub half-consciously at you ear, which still twinges every now and then from the whack you got earlier while marching.

         "Looks like you were right, Aze -this is the place. Let's see what they have been up to while we were gone."

         Emerging into the clearing, you all quickly cover your snouts. The unceremoniously heaped corpses of three adders are burning in the corner, just far enough away from the heavy undergrowth to avoid a forest fire, and putting up a smell every bit as horrible as the one they gave off in life. Next to them is a pile of what were likely the first unfortunate troops to enter the hall after you.

         In the clearing proper, several dozen soldiers of various species sit around random campfires, eating a meagre supper. Across the way stands a partially completed palisade that looks like it will soon ring the area around the front entrance, with a counterpart jutting from the opposite side of the entrance, near to the door.

         The front door in question is packed with more vermin hurrying in and out, carrying supplies, weapons, plunder, furniture, and other items both ways. Cluny and most of the other officers aren't to be found, with the exception of a few calling orders, but not at nearly as high a tempo as when you were forming up for marching earlier .

         As you eagerly step out into the open, a gruff voice calls out from the right.

         "Ahoy! You three! Stop and be counted!" A rat with an spear marches up, looking you all up and down, muttering to himself. "Looks like a group of lazies who snuck off when we were cleaning out the hall and buildin' that fence. Probably didn't wanna do anything dang'rous or hard. Rotten wibbles."

         In answer, Addon steps forward indignantly.

         "Hey! We're scouts who had to go in that there hole first and-"

         "Than what you doing up here? The hall's back there. Underground. Or didn't you notice?"

         "I was gonna say that! We were sent in first, and those serpents attacked us. They got two of us, and we barely escaped with out tails."

         "Un-hunh. And I thought ol' Scrap-ears and those stories of his about giant spiders with stingers like bees that live a thousand leagues southwards was crazy. You're prob'ly nothing but a group of short-term deserters who ran off when the Chief told us to charge, and came back when we was getting de loot together."

         "Yeah, where's the Chief? He's gotta know how we 'scaped. There's a secret tunnel!" Says Grigtail, leaning forward on his scythe.

         "In the main chamber. Hunh, I'll bet you got out by sprouting wings and flying to through the ground. Runs off when there's fightin’ to be doin‘, and then come back and tell a pack o' lies to a dedicated patroller. Hunh, I'll take you to the Chief all right! Foller' me."

         You all trade a mixture of irate and slightly worried glances. In retrospect, the idea that you had simply run away for a few hours when you had been ordered into battle seemed a lot more likely than you had gone in and then come crashing out of the bushes several hours later.

         No one would know you weren't lying, at least not completely, unless they had watched you go in earlier, or found Jubbra’s body. Which was probably guttering out right in the fire over yonder. He would have been assumed to be a casualty of the vermin’s later attack on the snake den.

         Hopefully the Warlord would at least let you show him the tunnel before passing judgement. Hopefully he wouldn't have anything better to do than listen to what simply appeared to be a group of yellow-bellies explaining themselves.
132122111111211111.title: Hero's Welcome?

1321221111112111111.content:
You follow the spear-beast down into the hall. It looks vastly different now-apparently even a marauding mob of vermin makes for a better caretaker than a group of snakes.

          Lanterns, candles, and torches are now scattered about. Already, many of the cobwebs have been swept away, and a few vermin are busy cutting back the encroaching roots. The main tunnel you had entered into earlier and only seen the opening segments of seems a lot smaller now that it's well lit. Soon it opens into a large central chamber, with half a dozen or so other doors and tunnels leading off of it in a rough elliptical pattern.

          A huge wooden column, which you realize in shock must be the huge old oak-tree’s tap-root, penetrates through the ceiling in the middle of the room, the lower reaches carefully carved into the shape of a massive throne. Dust stirred by the gentle summer breeze swirls lazily up and down the pathway, as the three of you plod steadily along, all suitably tired after a day of forced marches and battles. The red sun is long hidden by the great trees on either side, but it's last lengthy rays blaze powerfully through the wood pillars, colliding and silhouetting the dust clouds as they signal the crickets to begin their nocturnal chorus.

"So, what 'appened back there? How'd your lot know when to hit ours'?" Asks Grigtail, as the silence between you all lengthens like the shadows.

"Another traitor in your ranks, I suppose. Wouldn't be a big flippin' big surprise, wot? I heard somethin' about the higher ups on our side of the line mentioning that that Damug Warfang beast had sent 'em an envoy or some such sort, and the bloke told them that Cluny would be passing through here trying to cause havoc, and had asked Damug to bring his boys along to make life harder for us when we went to put 'em down. Damug refused him sharpish and told us about it, something 'bout hating Cluny more than us, wot, or so I heard before I had an encounter with some Juska, and got sent to the Far North."

The ferret nodded sagely, adjusting his scythe for a more comfortable position. "Must've been a Tuesday. Warfang's been crazier than two score mad frogs in a hole since the last time Rose Eyes done piked him. Nasty way to go it was for him, bein' skewed on an axe-pike. "

"Lady Crega Rose Eyes, doncha know! And did yu' ever see what happened to her after she charged Kharanjul's horde six seasons back in the deep south?"

"Well, if'n there was e'er something that could stand up to a mad badger, it'd be dem wearets; they could fight with the best at the worst of times. How'd it go on her?"

Feeling strangely out of touch as the two go on to half argue, half brag about their alignments exploits in some battle or other, you glance over into the gloom stretching off to either side of your way, the sun having reluctantly gone to it's bed some time ago. A faint, faerie glimmer in the depths of the foliage snags your gaze.

"Hay, what's that over there?" You say, gesturing with the blade of your sword.

Penny stops short and follows your pointing weapon. After a few moments of consideration, "Probably some beast havin' a little campfire, wot. Redwall's still a long way's off; let's go ask if they got any spare grub for some poor exhausted travelers." She says, starting eagerly into the brush.

"Hold-up, mates. I don't smell any wood-smoke here... But there is something like rotted eggs when the wind blows right. Ah don't like it."

"Don't know what kind of scoff smells like that, but I bet it's good. I can just picture it now; a little family of mice or voles or other travelers or some such, a nice cozy camp, and all kinds of delicious grub set out and toasty warm. Pasties and cheese sconce and flans and whatnot. C'mon now, sharpish, or I won't be savin' any for you!" She says, moving eagerly off the path. You and Grigtail exchange glances before following the hare.

Unused to your new senses, you wouldn't have noticed the absence of smoke on a still night such as this, but decide to differ to the ferret's judgement. And something doesn't feel right; the sensation is repetitively similar to the advance into Brockhall earlier, but without the bad smell. To boot, the mysterious light doesn't seem to be getting any larger as you all advance, tripping and stumbling in the dark. It just sits at eye-level, twinkling and glimmering strangely, too far off in the dense vegetation to be easily made out.

Penny maintains a personal commentary of the various varieties of 'scoff' awaiting you, the quiet sounds and Grigtail's muffled curses as he stumbles into the odd branch or shrub in the gloom the only noises. Even the crickets and night-birds have gone silent.

This occurs to you as queer just as Grigtail, close by to you right, yells something panicked and indecipherable.
"Grig? What happened? Grig?!" You call, hearing Penny crashing through the brush towards the shout. You step forward, and the ground seems to chuckle maliciously with almost sentient cruelty, sucking greedily at your paws as you begin sinking. You leap backwards again to solid ground, Penny calling out from somewhere near by.

"Watch out; it's a swamp-Unggh!"

Something strikes you in the back of the head, and you lash out reflexively with your sword as you tumble to the side. An outraged hissing sound fills the air- and you are hit again, flopping limply to the mud.

Two books are in it, the one you'd written, and the one you'd bought ten years ago.

"Are you finding everything alright?" a voice asks.

Examining yourself in the mirror, you don't know what to think. Blood pulses in your throat from nervousness, causing whiskers on either side of your pointed snout to flex. Amber furred with a white band around your middle, and a long, pink, worm-like tail sticking out the blankets, you stare. You stare some more. Open your mouth, see the sharp teeth inside, the little tongue. Pull faces, watching the reflection mimic every one.

That's me. That's actually me. I'm a rat? A jolt courses through, a sick, anxious feeling in the pit of your stomach. I look like the pet rat I had from when I was seven.

Shaking, you hand the mirror back to Sister Buttercup. "Thank you." Your voice sounds strange in your own throat, higher pitched from the shock.

"Are you alright?" Sister Buttercup tries a look of concern, but distaste shows on her slender mouse features.

"I'm in Redwall ..." You give yourself a quick pinch, just to make sure you were not dreaming. Redwall. Your favorite series of books, an Abbey set in the middle of Mossflower Woods, a sanctuary to woodland animals. If this was a dream, it was wonderful.

I'm in Redwall, and I'm a rat. Instantly, your stomach plummets again. A rat. A vermin. A member of the bad species, hated by the peaceful dwelling inhabitants of Redwall. Small wonder, when rats enjoyed plunder, murder, and conflict.

Then you smile.

You always used to think it was a shame, how the bad ones were always bad, and the good ones always good. Blaggut was always your favorite rat character in the books, the only decent one in the whole series, but only because he was too stupid to truly be bad.

You still feel like yourself.

Maybe you could be the first good female rat. Sister Buttercup asks again if you're okay.

"I hope so. Thank you for accepting me into your Abbey." You smile, making it as gentle as you can, lips closed. Your sharp teeth might otherwise alarm the tiny mouse in front. "I know what I look like."

"Hmm." Sister Buttercup nods, terse. "There's soup on the way, if you're hungry. And Martin would like to see you later, once you're recovered. Do you remember him, from earlier? He helped you."

You nod, suppressing the squeal on your lips. Martin the freaking Warrior? Oh hell yes.

"I see you do." Sister Buttercup smiles, seeing some of your enthusiasm. The infirmary door opens, and a squirrel wearing a brown habit steps in, a steaming bowl of stew clutched between their paws.

Already as you look into the mirror, you feel different. It is as if finally seeing yourself gives the boost needed, the last tip into that darkness writhing inside. Memories - what were memories? They faded. They became fuzzy, unclear. Insignificant. You take in your new features with relish. Creamy white with brown markings scattered over your sinuous, snake-like body. You especially enjoy how sharp your claws and teeth are. You hand the mirror back to Sister Buttercup.

I could snap her neck. Look at how small she is. How weak. You toy with the idea as Sister Buttercup puts the mirror away, but decide against it. There is no benefit in killing the frail mouse. At least not yet.

You don't know who your allies are yet, who you can join up with. Alone in an abbey surrounded by nauseatingly sweet creatures, you may as well be a prisoner. You just need to bide your time, see if the soft, fat pacifists in this place would be willing to house you, or force you on your way through Mossflower, once the injuries fully healed. Maybe then you could find other ferrets. Other vermin.

You smile disarmingly at Sister Buttercup, smoothing your features. "Thank you once again for taking me in, Sister. I will always be grateful for this."

Sister Buttercup blinks, then nods, looking strangely nervous. "Hum, yes. You're welcome."

Feeling a slight brush of cold, you pull the blankets more about yourself. Sister Buttercup sees the gesture, and very hesitantly places her paw over your forehead, testing the temperature. "You might be coming down with a fever. Small wonder, if you were in that water for a while. Winter waters are a terrible thing."

You close your eyes, giving a large, theatrical sigh. "Eh, I'm sure I'll be fine." The cold would prolong your stay in the abbey for sure. Whether this is a good or bad thing, you don't know.

There was one thing you did know. Sooner or later, this thirst for blood needs to be quenched. A sinister smile flutters over your lips.

They won't know what's coming for them at all, these fools.

info.brief_description: After an accident, you find yourself in the land of Mossflower. What now? 2,770+views.
info.description:
Ever since you could remember, you enjoyed reading the “Tales of Redwall” series. You loved reading about those heroic mice, and their friends, as they fought against those villainous rats, and their ilk. You cheered the heroes, Martin, Gonff, Matthias, and the other brave ones. You booed the villains, Badrang, Cluny, Slagar, and the other evil doers. You wailed at the deaths of Rose, Father Mortimer, and the others who gave their lives to protect the good people. Then, you were saddened to hear about the death of the Author and creator, Brian Jacques, just as his last book was published.

One dark and rainy evening, you managed to purchase the book that you needed to complete your collection of Redwall novels. However, on your way home there was an accident, with you being one of those in serious condition. Your hands are locked in Death’s grip on the book, as if it’s all that’s keeping you alive. Your physical body is attached to numerous machines, trying to keep you stabilized, while you remain in a coma. Your mind however, is in Mossflower Woods, near Redwall Abbey. Will you survive, and go back to the land of the living, or will you make the choice to stay?

Rules:

1. Anyone and everyone from any and every Redwall book could show up. This means that Heroes, such as Martin and Matthias and other good people, will come to help you, while Villains, such as Cluny and Badrang and other evil ones, will be out to try and do you harm, in one way or another. Also, original characters are allowed.

2. Death is not permanent. If someone in Mossflower, or the area around it, dies, they will come back after a time. (Similar to Riverworld) They will come back to life along the waterways, rivers, streams, ocean, sea, or on occasion, the Abbey pond, and they will be at their most physically fit age. For the most part, they will be given clothing, similar to those which they wore in life.

3. The characters can heal up from any wound that is non-fatal, though some will wear things that make them recognizable to others, such as Cluny’s use of his signature eyepatch. Thus, if one is to remove them, one must give them a “fatal” injury.

4. Should you “die”, there will be some problems for your body in the real world, mainly in the fact that you’ll be in the coma longer. So, try to not “die”.

5. Spelling and Grammar are a must, though if you try to do molespeech, or the speech of any who have an accent, some leeway will be given, but there is one thing: do it right or don’t do it at all. If you can’t do the accent, don’t even attempt. Nothing ruins a mole speech like a mole who can’t speak molespeech right.

6. Leadership of the peoples is interesting. Given the fact that there are many Abbots and Abbesses who have lead Redwall, from Abbess Germaine to Abbot Thibb, and many Badger Lords who have lead Salamandastron, from long before Lord Stonepaw to Lady Violet Wildstripe, whenever something important comes up, such as a vermin attack, the various Abbots and Abbesses, or Badger Lords, will talk among themselves before coming to a decision, at which point they will pick a speaker to talk to those under them.

7. Similarly, The Warriors of Redwall, who were chosen carriers of the Sword of Martin, from Martin the Warrior on down to Uggo Wiltud, tend to be in charge of the defense of the Abbey, and a leader will be chosen among them in the case of attack, and that one will be given the Sword, though if the foe is the enemy of a certain Warrior, that one will be given precedence.

8. As for the Leaders of Vermin, from Ungatt Trunn on down to Razzid Wearat, each one has their own crew/horde. For the most part, the various Vermin tend to fight among themselves, with each Leader trying to control the land/sea for themselves. However, there are times when the Leaders join forces with each other, so that they can accomplish a common goal, such as to conquer Redwall or Salamandstron or wherever, but each one will scheme and plot behind the others backs, in order to take over the Horde for themselves.

9. The Goodies tend to be mice, hares, moles, voles, shrews, otters, badgers, squirrels, hedgehogs, and some birds. *Note* There have been more than a few, who, due to how they were treated by others, insanity, or some other reason, who were not helpful, and would mistreat, or even kill, others. Examples include Skan, a shrew, Druwp, a vole, Tugga Bruster, a shrew (and Log-a-Log), and a few others.

10. The Baddies tend to be rats, ferrets, weasels, stoats, foxes, wildcats (or feral cats), wolverines, (which are thankfully rare), ermines, martens, polecats, and some birds. *Note* There have been a few who were actually good, or helped them out. Examples include Gingivere Greeneyes (and his wife and his distant descendant, Squire Julian Gingivere), wild/feral cats, Blaggut, searat, and a couple of others.

11. Your species is something of a quandary. Are you still human or have you turned into something that would live in Mossflower, or are you a changeling, with the ability to change your species depending on who, or what, is around you?

12. There are three groups of people- True Characters- those created by Brian Jacques, Fanfic- those made by Fans of the series (you can make them up), and finally Dead Fans- those whose souls have ended up in Mossflower instead of Regular Heaven. As for the creation of Mossflower- BJ read the first book to a kid dying of cancer. Kid said that he wished that Heaven was like Mossflower. Big Guy liked the story, and granted his wish. Since then, fans of the story ended up coming to Mossflower.

13. Sexual Orientation is up for Grabs- Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, Straight- all are fine, but limit the romance to hugging and kissing, for the time being.
